title: If It’s Worth Doing, It’s Worth Doing With Made-Up Statistics
summary:
Key ideas
- Imperfect information still provides some insight and is better than zero information
- Utilitarianism provides nonzero information transfer about the badness of North Korea and other difficult-to-quantify issues
- Intuitive decision-making often leads to significant errors in judgement

Key learnings
- Even if numbers are made up, applying arithmetic calculations to them can still provide valuable insight
- Utilitarianism may not be objectively correct but can provide useful information about difficult-to-quantify issues
- Made-up models can highlight errors in intuition and provide a second opinion without systematic bias

Key questions (asked by Scott)
- Why do I find the utility weights interesting even though they are not objectively correct?
- How can we quantify things we do not know how to quantify?
- Can making up numbers and applying calculations be more accurate than intuitive decision-making in some cases?
